sn35.231:0.3: 231. The Simile of the Latex-Producing Tree
sn35.231:1.1: “Mendicants, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, still has greed, hate, and delusion, and has not given them up. If even trivial sights come into their range of vision they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
sn35.231:1.3: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.
sn35.231:2.1: When it comes to sounds … smells … tastes … touches …
sn35.231:3.1: thoughts known by the mind, they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up. If even trivial thoughts come into the range of the mind they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
sn35.231:3.3: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.
sn35.231:4.1: Suppose there was a latex-producing tree—such as a bodhi, a banyan, a wavy leaf fig, or a cluster fig—that’s a tender young sapling.
sn35.231:4.2: If a man were to chop it here and there with a sharp axe, would latex come out?”
sn35.231:5.1: “In the same way, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, still has greed, hate, and delusion, and has not given them up. If even trivial sights come into their range of vision they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
sn35.231:5.3: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.
sn35.231:6.1: When it comes to sounds … smells … tastes … touches …
sn35.231:7.1: thoughts known by the mind, they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up. If even trivial thoughts come into the range of the mind they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
sn35.231:7.3: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.
sn35.231:8.1: Take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, has no greed, hate, and delusion left, and has given them up. If even compelling sights come into their range of vision they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.
sn35.231:8.3: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.
sn35.231:9.1: When it comes to sounds … smells … tastes … touches … thoughts known by the mind, they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up. If even compelling thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.
sn35.231:9.3: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.
sn35.231:9.4: Suppose there was a latex-producing tree—such as a bodhi, a banyan, a wavy leaf fig, or a cluster fig—that’s dried up, withered, and decrepit.
sn35.231:9.5: If a man were to chop it here and there with a sharp axe, would latex come out?”
sn35.231:9.8: Because it has no latex left.”
sn35.231:10.1: “In the same way, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, has no greed, hate, and delusion left, and has given them up. If even compelling sights come into their range of vision they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.
sn35.231:10.3: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.
sn35.231:11.1: When it comes to sounds … smells … tastes … touches …
sn35.231:12.1: thoughts known by the mind, they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up. If even compelling thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.
sn35.231:12.3: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.”
